coredata.dc:title: OH(A2Σ+ → X2∏) yield from photodissociation of H2O2 at 106–193 nm
coredata.dc:creator: Suto, Masako
Lee, L.C.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The absorption cross section of H2O2 and the (A2Σ+ → X2∏) fluorescence cross section of the resulting OH photofragments were measured in the 106–193 nm region using synchrotron radiation. The OH(A → X) emission has a significant cross section at excitation wavelengths shorter than 172.2 nm. Absorption structure observed in the 137–165 nm region is tentatively assigned.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 9S. number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 June 1983 Volume 98. numbe OH(A ^ - X 30) YIELD FROM PHOTODISSOCIATION OF H^O^ AT 106-193 nm Masako SUTO and L.C. LEE Department OJ Electrical anil Computer Engineering. San Diego State University, San Diego. California V2JS2. USA Received 20 December 1982 The absorption cross section of H;0:> Jnd the (A 2^ -> X2!!) fluorescence cross section of the resulting OH photofrag- inents '\ ere measured in the 106 193 nm region using synchrotron radiation. The OH(A -> X) emission has a significant cross section at c\ciUtion wavelengths shorter than 172.2 nm. Absorption structure observed in the 137 165 nm region is tenutivciv a.ssianed. 1. Introduction H\ drogen peroxide is an important atmospheric minor species which is related to tlie formation of acid rJin.The oxidation ofSO;> by H^07 eitherin gas phase or in a water droplet may be the main process for HiS04 formation [1]. i-hOi also contributes to the formation of HOy in tlie troposphere and in the strato- spliere [2]. In order to understand acid rain formation and atmospheric HO^. concentration, tlie information ofI^^O^ concentration is needed. The Ol-^A2^ -> X 2 II) emission from H-)O-> photodissociation can be used to develop techniques for H-)0^ detection, simi- lar to those used for H^O [3]. Studies ofH->Oi photodissociation processes are relatively few [4]. Tlie absorption cross section in the U V region ( 190-400 nm) lias been measured by sever- al auiliors [5-7] .but only one measurement has been made in tlie VUV region (X< 190 nm) [8]. Moreover, the U V and VUV data in the overlap region (185- 200 um) dre not consistent. The need for additional measurement in the VUV region was suggested by a previous investigator [9]. The OH(A 2 S-*- -^ X 211) emission was observed [10] from photodissociation ofH- 0-> with Kr (123.6 um) and Xe (147 nm) resonance lamps, but no emis- sion was observed at the mercury resonance line (184.9 nm). This contradicts thermochemical data [11,12] which suggest that the threshold wavelength for the H^O^ +hv-> OH (A) + OH(X) process should be 200 nm. Here we report the absorption cross section of H^O^ and tlie OH(A -> X) fluorescence cross section from H^O^ photodissociation using synclirotron radi- ation in the 106 193 nm region as light source. 2. Experiment The experimental apparatus has been described in detail in a previous paper [13]. Synchrotron radiation provided from the electron storage ring of the Univer- sity of Wisconsin was used as light source- It was dis- persed by a 1 m monochromator, and allowed to pass through a gas absorption cell. The synchrotron radia- tion flux was measured by a combination of a photo- multiplier tube (PMT) and sodium salicylate freshly coated on a window. The fluorescence intensities were measured in the direction perpendicular to the photon beam using a PMT (EMI 9558QB). The H^O^ sample of 90% purity supplied by FMC Corporation was kept m a teflon bottle placed inside a stainless container. Fresh vapor in the container was introduced into the gas cell through teflon valve and tubing since H^O- reacts with metal surfaces to form H^O and O^.The gas was continuously pumped by a Sorption pump to keep the gas pressure m the absorp- tion cell constant. The stainless container was contin- uously pumped the O^ concentr at22 Cwasmea manometer. 3. Results and d 3.1 Absorption i The absorptii tenuation of ph' 38.6 cm. It was tion of 0.2 nrn. The H^O^ sa water as the prii turc (22 C), the higher than thai during passage t acts on surfaces gas in the gas ce a small trace of 0-> can be subti trum using thei; The H20 am from their abso cross section of been well studi 0^ has discrete Schumann Ru gion. The absor 190nm region of strong band [13] and a con In the 106- section for the tic band struct! absorption con included in the this absorption H^O and 0, ni conditions. In 1 concentrations of total gas pri The absorpt given by 152 0 009-2614/83/0000-0000/S 03.00 1983 North-Holland Volume 98. number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 June 1983 uously pumped by a mechanical pump to minimize the Of concentration in the gas cell. The gas pressure at 22 C was measured by an MKS Baratron capacitance manometer. 3. Results and discussion 3.1 Absorption cross section The absorption cross section was measured by at- tenuation of photon flux in an optical path length of 38.6 cm. It was measured at a monochromator resolu- tion of 0.2 nm. The tl-,0-, sample liquid (90% purity) contains water as the principal impurity. At the room tempera- ture (22 C), the vapor pressure of H^O (=18 Torr) is higher than that of H^O^ (=1.4 Torr). In addition during passage through the apparatus, some H->0-> re- acts on surfaces to produce H^O and 0^. So the sample gas in the gas cell includes a large amount of H->0 and a small trace of 0->. However, the effects of H^O and 0-> can be subtracted out from the absorption spec- trum using their measured concentrations. The H^O and 0-> concentrations were measured from their absorption cross sections- The absorption cross section ofO-, in the 106 190 nm region has been well studied [4,14]. The absorption spectrum of 0^ has discrete structure in the 106 135 region, and a Schumann Runge continuum in the 135 180 nm re- gion. The absorption cross section ofH^Oin the 106 190 nm region is also well known [4,14]. It consists of strong band structure in the 106 140 nm region [13] and a continuum in the 140 190 nm region. In the 106 137 nm region, the absorption cross section for the total gas in the cell shows characteris- tic band structures of H-^O and Oi superimposed on absorption continuum. The H^O and 02 concentrations included in the sample gas are determined by comparing this absorption with the absorption strengths of pure H^O and 0, measured under the same experimental conditions. In the 0 100 mTorr pressure range the concentrations of H2 0 and C>2 are 59 1% and 3 0.5% of total gas pressure, respectively. The absorption cross section of H-^O-,, o^ o., 'ls given by ^0^ = ^-"H.O^OW-^W^H.O. oe where a(X), a^ Q (A) and OQ^ (A) are the absorption cross sections of sample gas, H-, 0 and O-, at wavelength X, respectively ;o.z.i o ,aii o and OQ are tlie frac- tions ofH-> 0->, H-> 0 and O^ concentrations in the gas ceU. The H^O^ absorption cross section obtained is slwwn in fig. 1. The experimental uncertainty is esti- mated to be within 15% of the given value, which includes 10% from absolute experimental uncertainty and 5% from the uncertainty in the H->0 and O-, con- centrations. The H3 O-, absorption cross section shows several small vibrational structures superimposed on the continuum in the 135 165 nm region. These structures belong solely to H-)O-}. because ti-,0 and 0-> do not show sucli features in this wavelength re- gion. At shorter wavelengths, the absorption is domi- nated by sharp H^O features so it is difficult to deter- mine whether or not the small H-> 0- vibrational struc- ture persists. The absorption cross section ofH->0-> in the VU V region has been measured bv Schurgers and Welge [8] - Their results differ significantly from our results- In the 160 170 nm region, their cross sections are about three times larger than those obtained here. In this re- gion, H^ 0 has a strong absorption continuum. It is like- ly that tile previous measurement was affected by H-> 0- In the UV region (X > 190 nm), the absorption cross P^OTQ^ E'-.'S^Y i eV ) 954_______S.27_______729 133 1-0 IM '50 WAVELENGT" t nm ' Fig. l. Absorption and fluorescence c'oss sections of HaO;. The absorption cross section measured by Holt et al- [5 ] and Lin et al. [7] are indicated by dotted line and triangle, res- pectively. Fluorescence starts to appear at 172.2 nm. 153 Volume 98. number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 June 1983 Volume 98, numt section has been measured by several groups [5 7]. Some ofllie previous results [5,7] are shown in ssg- 1 for comparison. The present result agrees well with the previous data. 3.2 Vibrational progressions The structures in the 137 170 nm are shown m more detail in fig. 2. The band structures are classi- fied into vibrational progressions as shown m fig. 2 and as listed in table 1. In the 155 167 nm region, t\vo progressions separated by 660 cm~1 are observed. Each progression has a vibrational frequency of 1350 cm~1. In the 143 153 nm region, an intense progres- sion of vibrational frequency Ar = 1140 cm~1 is also observed- Each member has two subbands with vibra- tional frequencies of 770 and 260 cm"1. The vibra- tional frequencies observed are tentatively assigned to various vibrational modes described below. H->0- lias a Ci symmetry and six fundamental vi- brations. The vibraiional frequencies ofH^O-; ground electronic state has been determined by infrared ab- sorption measurements [15]. According to these mea- surements. the vibraiional frequencies of VA (torsional oscillation). 2/3 (0 0 stretching), v^ (0 H asymmet- ric bending'), v^ (0 H symmetric bending), and 1/5 (0 H asymmetrical oscillation) are 465, 890,1266, T-ible l \\Jvenuinbers for H;0; .ibsorption spectrum 153 i60 ViA'tE-ENuti tnrr>) Fig. 2. Absorption spectrum ofHaOa in the 136-170 nm re- gion. Band structures are tentatively assigned. 2647, and 3610 cm"1, respectively. The vibrational frequencies of the excited electronic states are expected to be similar to the ground state. Thus, the observed frequencies of 260 and 770 cm-1 are tentatively as- signed to 1/4 and 1/3, respectively, and both the 1140 and 1350 cm"1 are assigned to different electronic states of VQ - These assignments are shown in fig. 2 and listed in table 1. The vibrational level at the longest wavelength is numbered as v = 0 for each progression- in the infrared absorption, the i/g progression is more intense than that ofvy and i'4. In the present measure- I irst series PQ + II Vf, "6 "0 + '"'6 + ^'3 "6 "3 U 59890 1320 60510 1370 620 1 6121U 1280 61880 1320 670 2 62490 1420 63200 1360 710 3 63910 64560 650 iver.igc 1340 1350 660 Second series It VO + 11 Vf, "6 Uo + llVf, + v^ "s KO + ""6 + "3 "6 "4 "3 0 65600 1110 65830 1170 66350 1130 230 750 1 66710 1110 66970 1150 67480 1140 260 770 2 67820 1190 68120 1130 68620 1130 300 800 3 69010 69250 69750 240 740 Jverage 1140 1140 1130 260 770 ment, the vg prc progressions. 3.3 Fluorescent The emission ation ofH-)0-) i -> X2^)syste^ trum produced Kr and Xe reso) tern [10]. The emissior a response in tri intensity from i ^=CFA/o^ where C is a ge( tion efficiency, tical path lengtl PMT view regio cross section, r species, and k i' cited species b> The pressure were studied at H^ 0 absorptiol lengths longer 1 H^O photodiss tensities at ail e pressure depen< in this experim system only. The emissioJ sample gas at e; fluorescence cr theOH(A-*X; whose cross sec section for the todissociation, from ^Oz^11 CTfHaoC^18111 HfO photodiss m this experim previous work The ssuoresi The emission ci 154 Volume 98, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 June 1983 ment, the Vg progression is also more intense than other progressions. 3.3 Fluorescence cross section The emission produced from the VUV photodissoci- ation ofH^O-> is expected only from the OHCA2^ -> X2!!) system. The previous dispersed emission spec- trum produced from photodissociation ofH^O^ by Kr and Xe resonance lamps shows this emission sys- tem [10]. The emission intensity was measured by a PMT with a response in the 190 800 nm region. The emission intensity from the excited photofragment is given by /,. = CFA/o^/p exp(-noZ)T;-1 /(T;-1 + kn), (2) where Cis a geometrical constant, F is the PMT detec- tion efficiency, / (7.4 cm) and A/ (2 cm) are the op- tical path length from the LiF window to PMT and PMT view region, respectively. Of is the fluorescence cross section, r,. is the radiative lifetime of excited species, and k is the quenching rate constant of ex- cited species by gas in the cell. The pressure dependences of emission intensities were studied at several excitation wavelengths of the H^O absorption peaks and minima and also at wave- lengths longer than 137 nm where no emission from H^O photodissociation is possible. The emission in- tensities at all excitation wavelengths show the same pressure dependence. Therefore, the emission observed in this experiment is obviously from the OH(A -> X) system only. The emission intensity from photodissociation of sample gas at each wavelength, X, ia put into absolute fluorescence cross sections, UfW, by comparing it with the OH(A -*- X) emission from H^O photodissociation whose cross section is well determined [13]. The cross section for the production of fluorescence H^0-> pho- todissociation, Of H Oi W at wavelength X is calculated from ^H^W = ^ - ^O^O00^^ - (3) ^fHioMls ^le cross section for fluorescence from Hi O photodissociation at A. Ofri Q was measured again in this experiment, and found to agree very well with previous work [13]. The fluorescence cross section is shown in ssg. l. The emission cross section becomes significant at 172.2 nm. The fluorescence has been observed at the longer excitation wavelengths, but the cross sections are too small to be measured accurately. The fluorescence cross sections increase with decreasing wavelengths, reaching a maximum at 115 nm, and decreasing at shorter wavelengths. In the 137 150 nm region, weak vibrarional structures of frequencies ^1000 cm"1 are observed. They are somewhat correlated to the adsorp- tion structures observed m the same wavelength region- The experimental uncertainties are estimated to be within 30% of given values. 3.4 Quantum yield The quantum yield is calculated as a ratio of flu- orescence cross section to absorption cross section at each wavelength shown in fig-1 - The quantum yields for the absorption continua are shown in fig. 3. The weak structures in the absorption and fluorescence cross sections are not included in the quantum yield calculation. The wavelength thresholds for the disso- ciation processes that are energetically possible for the OH(A) production are also indicated in fig. 3. The OH(A -> X) emission has small quantum yield at wavelengths longer than 172.2 nm, so the threshold energy for production of the OH(A -> X) emission is not well determined. The small quantum yield at the threshold wavelength may suggest that the OH(A) is produced by a single repulsive state. This suggestion is corroborated by the fact that at wavelengths longer than 170 nm the absorption spectrum of H-,0-, is a 130 KO 150 WAVELENGTH ( nm ) Fig. 3. Quantum yield for production of the OH(A -> X) emis- sion from HaOa photodissociation. The thresholds for the dis- sociation processes that produce OH(A) are indicated. 155 Volume 9S. number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 June 1983 Volume 98, numbi continuum. In the threshold wavelength region, the Franck Condon overlap between the repulsive state and ilic ground state may be small, so the quantum \ ields are small. At the wavelengths shorter than 170 nin. structures appear in both absorption and fluores- cence cross sections- This indicates that bound states exist in this region. The increase of the OH(A -> X) fluorescence yield may arise partly from bound states. Since H^O-) is a non-linear molecule, both photo- I'rdgnients OH (A) and OH(X) are expected to be highly rotatioridlly excited in the fragmentation process f 1 (-1]. The excess energy could be shared by both frag- ments mainly as rotational energy. In the photolysis of 11 -lO-, ai 193 nm (ArF laser), highly rotationally ex- cited OH(X) photofragments were observed [17]. The highly rotational excitation ofOH(A) fragment was also observed when H->0;? was photolyzed by Xe and Kr resonance lamps [10]. 4. Conclusion Tlie photoJbsorption cross section ofH->0-) is mea- sured in the 106 193 um region. The current results arc different from the previous results in the VUV re- gion [8] but show good agreement with results ob- tained JI wavelengths longer than 190nin [5.7]. Struc- tures observed in the 137 170 nm region are classified into vibrdtiondl modes in accord with the vibrational modes of the ground state [15]. The cross section for tlie production ofOH(A - X) fluorescence is also measured in this experiment. head.ce:title: OH(A2Σ+ → X2∏) yield from photodissociation of H2O2 at 106–193 nm

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, San Diego State University, San Diego, California 92182, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The absorption cross section of H2O2 and the (A2Σ+ → X2∏) fluorescence cross section of the resulting OH photofragments were measured in the 106–193 nm region using synchrotron radiation. The OH(A → X) emission has a significant cross section at excitation wavelengths shorter than 172.2 nm. Absorption structure observed in the 137–165 nm region is tentatively assigned.
